Current Level of AI Usage

AI in robotics is high and still rising. Modern robots rely on AI for perception (vision/SLAM), planning (A*/trajectory optimization), and autonomy (reactive, probabilistic, and learning-based control)1 across most major sectors.

Landmark surveys and tutorials document this arc from symbolic planning to probabilistic SLAM and learning-driven autonomy now fielded in hospitals, warehouses, and planetary missions.2

Historical Growth of AI in Robotics

1960s–1970sFirst AI Robot Era: Shakey fuses vision, planning, and action.
1980sBehavior-Based Control: Subsumption architecture for real-time autonomy.
1990s–2000sProbabilistic Robotics & SLAM: Bayesian navigation and mapping.
2010sDeep Perception: Large-scale deployments, resilient autonomy.
2020sLearning-Based Control: Fielded autonomy in hospitals, space, and surgery.

First Known AI Application

  • Shakey the Robot (1966–1972): First mobile system to perceive, plan, and act using integrated AI.
  • Combined computer vision, symbolic planning, and action execution.
  • Set the template for future AI-driven robotics.
  • Demonstrated autonomous navigation and task completion.

Foundational Methods

  • A* Search: Heuristic pathfinding for navigation and manipulation.
  • Subsumption Architecture: Layered, reactive control for robust autonomy.
  • SLAM: Bayesian estimation for localization and mapping.
  • T-RO Survey: Reviews and tutorials underpin robust perception.

AI Usage Over Time

  • Symbolic era: Search/planning (STRIPS, A*).
  • Reactive era: Subsumption for real-time behavior.
  • Probabilistic era: SLAM and Bayesian estimation.
  • Learning-driven era: Robust perception and autonomy in fielded robots.

Conclusion

AI usage in robotics is high. The record shows a steady progression from symbolic AI to learning-based autonomy, with mission-critical deployments and domain-specific robots. Multiple scholarly sources confirm broad, mature, and expanding AI adoption.
